This contribution was written by myself twenty years ago presumably for presentation at an entertainment in Saltcoats. It concerned the status of the North American Indian of Canada and in perusing it, I thought it might be of interest to some who delve into ancient history and is a resume of the Indian situation past, present and future.

Of his past, there is much of colorful interest, of his present state there is much that is but little known or cared of and his future is stamped with the seal of early extinction.

Like the Dodo and the Great Ark of the bird kingdom the North American Indian is doomed as a distinct race of pure blood to utter extermination.

A study of the Indian races of North America shows a mortality, a death rate abnormally high, a decrease so enormous that, like the buffalo, soon nought but a remnant of a once powerful race will remain. In looking up statistics of the numbers of Canadian Indians, this is what I record in 1917, 14 yrs. ago a census showed a numbering of 105 thousand souls in the whole of Canada. About 2 yrs ago an educated Indian, a Rotarian, visited the Rotarian club in Yorkton. He spoke at length and his speech was printed word for word in the Yorkton Enterprise. His statements were extraordinary, his statistics appalling, at that time he gave a number of 87,000 remaining Indians this was a decrease of 10,000 in eleven years so at this rate of loss approximately 55 years will consume the remaining residue of the once nominal owners of this Canadian country.

Shall we as a people view with complacency this passing of a once, in many respects noble race. My own personal observations of the Indian, a Metis nation extends back to the years 1883, nearly 48 years ago when, I, as a boy, came to Canada as a British immigrant. Arriving at Broadview on the main line C.P.R. we journeyed by covered wagon to Crescent city as it was termed on the gorgeously red inked map, a distance of nearly 50 miles, and my first sight of N. A. Indians was at the ferry crossing the Qu'Appelle River. A tall, blanketed moccasined representative carrying the inevitable muzzle loader met us, and upon payment of the usual fee, ourselves, wagons and belongings were ferred across the stream.

We were destined in the next ten years to come in contact with them almost daily, at certain season of the year and had first hand opportunity of studying and becoming acquainted with the life and habits of the noble red man as he had been termed by writers of song and story.

After nearly fifty years of acquaintance with these people as I have found them as a nation, they are honorable, they are honest, to a certain extent trustworthy if you do not tempt them too long, too far. And among the true blood Indians that I have known, their mortality is of a higher standard that that of the whites. I have never lost a dollar either by theft or by trade with them very much more than I can say in favor of the trade and barter with Canadians. The Indian is a shrewd bargainer, a habit rendered necessary in order to compete successfully with those ready to fleece him. A faithful friend to those he deems worthy and he will suffer in silence extremes of hunger or cold, before he will ask for assistance from unsympathetic sources. He is at all times ready to accept gifts of food or clothing suitable to his needs, but cannot accustom himself to foods and clothing such as some people might think acceptable.

It was the year 1885. The Indian rebellion under the direction of Louis Riel was causing considerable trouble on the plains of the then Assiniboia. I, a boy of 10, left alone in charge of my younger brother and sister, was startled by a young man rushing into the house, badly frightened and in fear of his life. He was quite new to the country and what he had seen seemed to him to be an approaching massacre. He had run two miles to tell his news, which was a mass demonstration by the local Indians, aided and abetted by some young men of neighboring tribes who had incited them to violence. My father was contacted and, leaving the young man from the East with the two younger children, my father and I set off for the settlement where the Indians had congregated. On the way we met a good Indian we called John coming to see us to tell us he was doing all he could to keep the others in hand but wanted my father to be there and assist Mr. Eakin, the head of the colony, in controlling the bad element among the throng. Before reaching the Village of Crescent Lake (two or three houses and some tents) we heard the discharge of firearms and feared the worst. Upon arrival we were just in time to see a body of Indians, four abreast, about 30 men in all, headed by one Indian chief, Oka Neesh, (In English, "little bones") of the local reserve, trotting into the main thoroughfare before the Hotel maintained and operated by a huge man of 300 pounds known by the sobriquet of "Jumbo" Salisbury. Scattered about were 100 squaw-men, women and children, their ponies, travois and two-wheeled Red River carts with colts, dogs and the commissariat of a large tribe of natives. The fighting men and their leader, Oka Neesh, were stripped to breech-clouts and moccasins and painted to the full in war paint - red, black and yellow. Also, some of the large papooses were similarly painted in imitation of their fathers. An interpreter, John Fox by name, dressed in white man's clothes, and a half-breed, stepped forward and was met by Mr. Eakin, my father, Will Anderson, Switzer and Thompson.

Accosted by Mr. Eakin (a fearless, forceful man, later a member of the Provincial legislature) as to what this demonstration meant, the half-breed gave this explanation.

The rebellion of Louis Riel was on, some local successes had made the Indians war-mad. The object was to subdue the white man by force if necessary and this was a start locally to help the uprising along. The Indians wanted arms, ammunitions and food in large quantities. If refused, they meant to use force to acquire it. Some of the younger men were hard to control. Some people might get hurt. Better to agree to their demands and save bloodshed. Mr. Eakin (a diplomat) listened carefully and said "Yes, but first, let us hold a council campfire and a pow-wow. Let the people form up and get the music of the tom drums going. Then we will talk the whole thing over." The interpreter explained fully to Oka Neesh the suggestion, and after some bantering, he finally agreed and gave the order to the tribe to get busy. Instantly, as evening was approaching, everyone got busy gathering firewood and, selecting a site for the pow-wow on a long hillside. Mr. Eakin then issued some rations to the Indians, flour, tea and sowbelly, and wisely first fed and watered the hungry hoard.

An outer ring of the main body, the pow-wow circle, consisting of the squaw-men, the squaws, young and old, ranging down to papooses, wapoooses and even some babes slinging in their cradles on the backs of their devoted mothers, made up a concourse of approximately 75 souls. The musicians, with their tom-toms and beating sticks, squatted cross-legged on the ground within the outer circle and, at the order to let loose, the din began. "Tum-tum, tum-tum, tum-tum". As the Scotch sons of the bag-pipers respond, so did the Indian nation, and in a short time every man, woman and child in the outer circle were swaying and weaving to the monotonous vibrations of the tom-toms. "Tum-tum, tum-tum". They were inspired. An aged man in breech-clout only sprang up, gesticulated loudly and fired his musket in the air.

The pow-wow was on and round and round the natives girated. Fifteen minutes or so and a halt was called. Silence. The chief—Okan Neesh, the interpreter and Mr. Wm. Eakin advanced to the centre. As it was a war-time gesture, no pipe was offered, which was synonymous and not to the occasion. Oka Neesh spoke first. He was a fiery man, six feet, raw boned and not at all handsome. A typical savage, dressed in belt and war bag with the raw-hide sheath and big knife hanging handy, he also painted red, black and yellow, with eagle feathers in his hair hanging in two plaits down his back. He summarized briefly. The Indians had a grievance. The Government had not lived up to its promises. It had usurped their lands. The whit man had killed off all the buffalo, had burned up the prairies destroying all the natural game. The Indians were starving, were, in fact, desperate, so leaders had undertaken to drive out the white man and bring things back, once more, to a normal condition. Now, they wanted arms and munitions. They wanted all the food there was, and, in short, were there to take possession by force, if necessary. He fired his gun off into the air. The Chief had spoken.

Mr. Eakin asked for No. 2 to speak. He was ready. He sprang into the circle. He was a hot rod. First he gazed up into the ether where the stars were twinkling. He made mystic grimaces. He gesticated to an unseen audience. The spirits apparently responded and gave him inspiration. He fired his gun into the air. He drew his big knife and whirled in menacingly round and about. Mr. Eakin ignored him, then told him to quit and speak his piece. He did, and the interpreter did his best to convey his harangue. It was idle boasting and he finally blew up and sank down with a sense of duty well done. No. 3 followed, No. 4 after him, until about six had spoken. The Chief called a halt and handed the floor to Mr. Eakin (later Speaker in the Provincial legislature).

Having been urged to recount incidents of long past years, my memory reverts to the days of the year 1885, reminiscent of the Indian Rebellion of that time. Being a resident in the school district of Crescent Lake, contiguous to the Indian Reservation of Little Bones Reserve.

This Reserve (since liquated) held a roaming population of close to one hundred souls, plus a large band of Cajuse Shaganapps, and a motley collection of the manjiest half-starved mongrel curs it was possible to acquire.

A visit to the reserve at this time revealed a menagerie of Indian Flatsman and Jetsona, once seen not easily forgotten. At this time and place you saw the population at its worst and best. Some well dressed young bucks, plus Blanket & Bshirt; buckskin leggings and of course moccasins with elaborate beas-work in various designs; a belt from which hung a war bag as it was termed, containing gun caps, pipe (Shawgun), Kini Kini or Indian tobacco, made from the inner bark of the Red willow Bush, a few matches or flint box, and moss just in case—but no birth certificate or coin of the realm. Also in a rawhide was a sheath, a big IO inch knife, sharp, capable of cutting down a young tree, skinning game, cutting tobacco, or scalping an enemy. I once saw severed very nice ones, this pastime is now held in abeyance.

The squaws were a sorry lot, several maidens of age to sit upon the brush were passable, but for the most part were burden bearers, and looked it. They never rested, always getting firewood, making fires, but very little dishwashing as the mongrel curs were very helpful and easily obtained. Cooking was a simple matter, a huge iron pot held a collection of comestibles, difficult to obtain at local stores, but greedily devoured by all and sundry. Choice pots often contained portions of skunk or badger, a few gophers or squirrels, these smaller ones invariably evisterated but usually left with the skins on, hair scorched off, this adding a distinct flavour reminiscent of pepper, no salt used. Anything else digestible was liable to be added as occasion warrant.

And swift the happy days of long ago sped, no taxes, no rent to pay, a hunting credit at the H.B. stores long past overdrawn, and the Indian was a happy man but always ready to acquire more credit.

But I started to recount a little episode that occurred to me personally. It was about the month of August 1885. The Rebellion was in full swing. Some outlying settlers had been brutally murdered, some soldiers had been ambushed and slain, officered by men who knew little about hunting so men were knocked off like pins or bush rabbits. They had to learn the hard way and officers don't like to be told by ordinary people how to go about taming the savage who liked to kill at close range with ineffective weapons.

I being an oldster of 12 years was left alone in charge of two younger children, &c. Our parents were away working at the village of Crescent Lake, comprising a store, and an immense Hotel of two stories, dimension of 18 by 22 feet, with an addition of a log kitchen paved with logs rudely flattened in which building appetizing meals were served ad libitum.

Instantly my little sister screamed and vanished. We discreetly retired to the house and waited for developments. The Indian had probably seen us before we saw him so after thinking the matter over I decided to go out and see what was to be done about it. A nimble little pony completed a perfect picture of a fighting native, completely overawed a little mone-ass papoose, i in short I was beneath his notice and apparently he was deciding what was to be done about me.

I was distinctly perturbed myself and while I was used to Indians I didn't like the looks of this guy.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.).

Only rough trails, eight of us in one wagon, men and boys mostly walked. Indians at Quappelle all carried guns and knives. Prairie chickens were everywhere, ducks covered the sloughs. Mosquitoes very large, lots of them would weigh a pound, and they climbed up on the trees and back. Two miles out we met by an ox team to bid us welcome, and one man came at least 10 miles out to meet us. They proved to be great friends to us. We gave them work to trade at the store for wages, no money was used only barter credit. Flour, B powder, tea, and a little brown sugar. Beans and hardtack was dished out nightly. Also, some cheese, sour milk, this was a life saver. Bunches thick. Shot lots of ducks and prairie chickens.
